awd_titl_txt: ISS: Flame Spread in Confined Spaces - Study of the Interactions between Flame and Surrounding Walls
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on the study of fire behavior and flame spread in confined spaces. Structure fires account for approximately 82% of civilian deaths and 72% of property damage among all fire types, according to the 2015 U.S. data. By providing a fundamental understanding of the interactions between spreading flames and their confining walls, this project will help enable safer designs and improved fire safety codes. These will ultimately reduce property losses, injuries, and fatalities. The primary activity is the combustion experiment that will be conducted aboard the International Space Station (ISS). The microgravity conditions on the ISS enable a systematic examination of how fires respond to different air flow environments in confined spaces. The investigators will also use their state-of-the-art computational tools to model the combustion process in great detail. In addition to the educational opportunity to graduate students, this project will also provide rare opportunities for college and high school students to be "on console" at the NASA Glenn Research Center to have the first-hand experience of space experiment operations. 

The hypothesis of this research is that under certain conditions, flame spread in confined spaces is a continuously accelerating process and may pose an even more serious fire hazard than flame spread in open spaces. The mechanisms that allow this to occur are radiative heat feedback from the surrounding walls and the tunnel flow acceleration effect. The goal is to examine this hypothesis by characterizing flame-wall aerodynamics and thermal interactions. Tests of concurrent-flow flame spread over flat samples will be conducted in a small flow duct in the microgravity environment, where buoyancy is essentially eliminated, and the forced flow is imposed on the sample independent of other parameters. A wide range of parameters will be tested, including the duct height, sample material, duct wall surface properties, and flow speed. This will be accompanied by an in-house transient computational model. The computational results will help interpret the experimental data and allow extrapolations to other situations and geometries with realistic fire scales. The outcome of this project will provide missing knowledge and lead to a more complete understanding of the flame spread process in confined spaces. The experimental data will yield valuable information to enhance the computational fire model. The resulting model will allow re-interpretation of current and past research results in light of the new findings, which will lead to new discoveries in fire science.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project studied material flammability and fire behaviors in different confined spaces. Specifically, it investigated the thermal and aerodynamic interactions between spreading flames and their surrounding walls. During the project period, the following were accomplished: 1) burning experiments at Case Western Reserve University, 2) microgravity experiments using the Zero Gravity Research Facility (a 5.2 s drop tower) at NASA Glenn Research Center, 3) experiments aboard the International Space Station (ISS), and 4) numerical modeling. The combination of comprehensive experiments and numerical simulations allowed a model of underlying physics of flame spread in confined spaces to be developed, implemented, and validated against reality. Also, the developed model allowed re-interpretation of current and past experimental results. Through these, this project provided missing knowledge and led to a more complete understanding of flame spread process in confined spaces.

Research findings were disseminated to the scientific community through publications and presentations. The research results were published in 6 journal articles, 6 conference articles, 5 invited talks, and additional 7 oral or poster presentations in conferences. The Principal Investigator (PI) and her students also visited and presented the project results to their industry partners (e.g., UL and FM Global). Through close collaborations with standards and certification bodies, research findings in this project have great potential to be translated into fire safety codes and influence the development of future structures and products. For example, the findings can be used to assess potential fire hazards in existing confined spaces (e.g., transportation vehicles, tunnels, buildings, warehouses, and spacecraft). The findings also provide guidance for how to optimally design the geometry of a confined space, and to suggest interior materials (or wall treatments) for such spaces.

Various student opportunities were provided by this project, including the following: 1) research opportunities for Ph.D., MS, and undergraduate students at Case Western Reserve University, 2) research opportunities for high school students in the Greater Cleveland area, 3) opportunities to interact with NASA scientists/engineers, 4) access to microgravity experiments, and 5) first-hand experience to ISS operations. Funding received from NSF has supported four graduate students and a number of undergraduate students. Five high school students were involved in this project through conducting Summer or year-long research in the PI?s lab. These students were given the opportunities to conduct or observe drop tower experiments and interact with scientists at NASA Glenn Research Center. They were also given the opportunities to publish journal articles and present in conferences. Last, this project provided rare opportunities for students to have first-hand real-time experience of space experiment operations. Students were invited to be "on console" at the NASA Glenn Research Center during the ISS experiment operations. The rich set of data collected in the ISS experiments and the numerical model will continually provide research opportunities to students in the years to come. In addition to providing research opportunities, this project positively impacted college curriculum and classroom experience. The project outcomes (including videos, analyzed data, and findings) were shared in the PI's courses (e.g., EMAE353 Heat Transfer, EMAE/EMAC 463 Fire Dynamics, EMAE/EMAC464 Fire Protection Engineering). Through this, the PI helped students relate the fundamentals covered in the lectures to research projects and to real-world problems.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2023
Modified by: Ya-Ting T Liao

Images (1 of )
  • Astronaut Christina Koch setting up a sample for experiment aboard the International Space Station in December 2019.
    NASA
    Public Domain
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Microgravity experiments aboard the ISS
  • Example result from the ISS experiments: flame development leading to a steady spreading state in a concurrent flow in a confined space. Ignition is at lower left. Images are 2.8 s apart, left to right, bottom row to top row. Flow speed: 6 cm/s. Confined conditions: 5.0 cm, black surrounding walls.
    NASA
    Public Domain
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Example result from ISS experiments - steady spreading flame
  • Example result from the ISS experiments: a continuously growing flame in a concurrent flow in a confined space. Ignition is at lower left and images are 2.3 s apart, left to right. Imposed flow velocity: 28 cm/s. Confined conditions: 5 cm, reflecting surrounding walls.
    NASA
    Public Domain
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Example result from ISS experiments - growing flame
  • Results from the ISS experiments revealed the effects of confinement on flame profiles. In the tests shown in this figure, the surrounding wall was black (no reflection) and the imposed flow speed was 6 cm/s.
    NASA
    Public Domain
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Effects of confinement on flame profiles
  • Results from the ISS experiments revealed the effects of radiation properties of surrounding walls on flame profiles. In the tests shown in this figure, the confined condition was 4.0 cm and the imposed flow speed was 6 cm/s.
    NASA
    Public Domain
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Effects of radiation reflection on flames
  • The numerical model developed in this project (shown on the right panes) successfully captured the concurrent-flow flame spread process observed in the ISS microgravity experiments (shown on the left panes). The black contours in the numerical results are iso-lines of fuel vapor reaction rate.
    Ya-Ting Liao
    Copyrighted
    Ya-Ting T Liao
    Numerical modeling of flame spread in a confined space
